title: Billy Ott
text:
William Joseph Ott (November 23, 1940 – February 18, 2015) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> player, an <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> whose six-season (1960–1965) career included stints with the and <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a> of <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>. A <a href="switch%20hitter">switch hitter</a> who threw <a href="right-handed">right-handed</a>, Ott stood tall and weighed in his playing days. He signed with the Cubs after graduating from <a href="Cardinal%20Hayes%20High%20School">Cardinal Hayes High School</a> in <a href="Bronx%2C%20New%20York">the Bronx</a> and attending <a href="St.%20John%27s%20University%20%28New%20York%29">St. John's University</a>.
Ott earned a late-season recall to Chicago after his best <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor league</a> campaign, when he hit 23 <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a> and compiled 88 <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a> for the 1962 <a href="San%20Antonio%20Missions">San Antonio Missions</a> of the Double-A <a href="Texas%20League">Texas League</a>. He appeared in 12 <a href="games%20played">games</a> and on September 17 he hit his only Major League home run, a solo shot off <a href="Ray%20Washburn">Ray Washburn</a> of the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a>. In 1964, he was called up from the Triple-A <a href="Salt%20Lake%20City%20Bees">Salt Lake City Bees</a> in June and was the immediate successor to <a href="Lou%20Brock">Lou Brock</a> as the Cubs' starting <a href="right%20fielder">right fielder</a> on June 16. Brock had been <a href="Brock%20for%20Broglio">traded to the Cardinals</a> a day earlier in what would come to be considered as one of the more one-sided transactions in MLB annals. Ott collected one <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hit</a>, a <a href="double%20%28baseball%29">double</a>, off <a href="left-hander">left-hander</a> <a href="Dennis%20Bennett%20%28baseball%29">Dennis Bennett</a> of the <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a> on the day. He would start four more times in right field during the next week, but registered only four hits in 22 <a href="at%20bats">at bats</a> during that time, and he returned to the minor leagues after his final Cub appearance in mid-July.
All told, Ott played in 32 Major League games and batted 67 times, with 11 hits. Upon leaving baseball, he became a police officer and a professional <a href="locksmith">locksmith</a> in his native New York City.
